IU tops Purdue 23-16 to retain Old Oaken Bucket

David Woods, david.woods@indystar.com 4:52 p.m. EST November 29, 2014

    10 CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

    BLOOMINGTON Freshman quarterback Zander Diamont scored from the 1-yard line with 27 seconds left, capping an Indiana comeback in a 23-16 football victory over Purdue on Saturday.

    The outcome ended a six-game losing streak by the Hoosiers (4-8, 1-7) and gave them their first Big Ten victory of the season. They also won back-to-back games for the Old Oaken Bucket for the first time in two decades.

    Junior running back Tevin Coleman carried 29 times for 130 yards in what might have been his final game for the Hoosiers. He could leave school early and declare for the NFL draft.

    Coleman padded his total to 2,036 yards and became the 18th player in Football Bowl Subdivision history to exceed 2,000 in a season.

    Purdue's Akeem Hunt carried 19 times for 171 yards, featuring an 82-yard touchdown, before leaving with an undisclosed injury.

    It was the sixth consecutive loss for the Boilermakers (3-9, 1-6).

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Indiana basketball fends of UNC-Greensboro, 87-79

    Coleman left the game briefly and had his ankle re-taped. He could have cost Indiana the game with a fumble but was bailed out by IU's defense, Diamont and backup running back D'Angelo Roberts.

    Diamont led the Hoosiers on an eight-play, 65-yard drive for the winning touchdown. Roberts rushed for 15 and 14 yards on successive plays to reach the 1. On the next play, Diamont faked to Roberts and went into the end zone untouched.

    Diamont completed 15-of-24 passes for 119 yards. Shane Wynn caught six passes leaving him two short of Indiana's career record for 47 yards.

    Purdue quarterback Austin Appleby was 19-of-35 for 123 yards and had three passes intercepted.

    Coleman fumbled on the first play of the fourth quarter, giving Purdue possession at the Indiana 24. But for the third time in as many red-zone incursions, the Boilermakers were kept out of the end zone. Paul Griggs' third field goal pushed Purdue ahead 16-13.

    Coleman wasn't benched after the fumble, as he was earlier this season. His runs of nine and eight yards opened a drive that culminated with Griffin Oakes' third field goal, a 34-yarder that tied the score at 16 with 6:31 left.

    The Hoosiers tied the score at 13 late in the third quarter when Wynn took the ball from Coleman on a reverse and raced 41 yards for their first touchdown. It was a play that Indiana has often run since mid-season, and it was a play that invariably works because defenses devote so much attention to Coleman.

    Early in the third quarter, the Hoosiers' third interception by linebacker Tegray Scales gave them the ball at the Purdue 23. They appeared to be stopped when Diamont was sacked at the 18 and fumbled on third-and-8.

    However, Coleman recovered the fumble, and after the resultant scrum Purdue linebacker Danny Ezechukwu collided with an official. Ezechukwu was ejected for a personal foul, and Indiana was awarded 15 yards and an automatic first down.

    The Hoosiers still couldn't score after running seven plays inside the Purdue 20. They settled for their first points, a 23-yard field by Oakes.

    But on Purdue's first play after the kickoff, Hunt wove through the Indiana defense, picked up some downfield blocking and ran 82 yards for the game's first touchdown. The score expanded the Boilermakers' lead to 13-3.

    Indiana scored again on its next possession, sparked by Diamont's 23-yard pass to senior Nick Stoner, who had missed two games with a leg injury. Oakes' 41-yard field goal pulled the Hoosiers within 13-6.

    Purdue committed three turnovers in the first half but still came out of it with a 6-0 lead.

    Griggs' two field goals, both from 26 yards, were the difference.

    Purdue's first turnover came when Appleby's pass to Hunt was ruled a fumble. Indiana linebacker T.J. Simmons returned the ball to the Purdue 35. But the Hoosiers' offense sputtered to a standstill, and Oakes' 38-yard field goal attempt barely cleared the line of scrimmage and was no good.

    The Boilermakers' first scoring drive was methodical -- 59 yards in 14 plays before ending at the Indiana 9. Griggs proceeded to kick his first field goal.

    In his first carry after returning to action, Coleman ran 20 yards to the Indiana 30. The Hoosiers faltered again, as they did after safety Chase Dutra intercepted Appleby's long downfield pass.

    Wynn foolishly dove in an attempt to catch a Purdue punt, fumbling the ball away at the Indiana 20. But the Hoosiers again held on defense, limiting Purdue to another field goal with 2:59 left in the half.

    Purdue's third turnover was an interception by IU cornerback Michael Hunter near the end of the half.

    Call Star reporter David Woods at (317) 444-6195.
